issue.title: Rclone creates (or logs that is creating) empty directories on every sync

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

Rclone creates (or logs that is creating) empty directories on every sync

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

Current git

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)

Linux, 64

####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)

Local file system for testing

#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

```
cd /tmp
mkdir t1
mkdir t1/empty
rclone -vv copy t1 t2
rclone -vv copy t1 t2
```


#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

Both the copy commands produce this log

```
2019/02/15 11:02:38 DEBUG : empty: Making directory
```

Rclone should know while it is traversing the tree about the empty directories in the source so it shouldn't have to make them.

body:
> This should be fixed in [1b52f8d](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/commit/1b52f8d2a5f95905e3ce9b6e843e6242cae8683c)

The problem persists. Removing the --create-empty-src-dirs doesn't fix the problem, since it won't ever create empty dirs (which I need, since they indicate that an operation was executed before).

The new test was performed with this new flag added, and resulted on the same behavior as before.

[1b52f8d] doesn't fix the feature as much as it removes it. 

Thank you for the feedback.

> @aldones sorry, I didn't understand the issue at first.
> 
> The expected behavior is for rclone dry run sync to ignore empty directories that already exist on the destination.
> 
> Thank you for the clarification, I'll try to this as soon as possible.

Something that might be related, or might be a completely different issue, is that when you rename a directory, instead of renaming the directory on the destination, rclone will create a new directory with the new name, move the files to the new directory, and remove the old one. This is for google drive only, as far as I can tell.

Looks like rclone is doing something weird when handling directories. Or maybe the API is weird.

But somehow I've got a feeling that these 2 issues are related.

> Something that might be related, or might be a completely different issue, is that when you rename a directory, instead of renaming the directory on the destination, rclone will create a new directory with the new name, move the files to the new directory, and remove the old one. This is for google drive only, as far as I can tell.

What is your command line for this?  Where are you renaming the directory?  You might want to check out the [--track-renames](https://rclone.org/docs/#track-renames) flag

> > Something that might be related, or might be a completely different issue, is that when you rename a directory, instead of renaming the directory on the destination, rclone will create a new directory with the new name, move the files to the new directory, and remove the old one. This is for google drive only, as far as I can tell.
> 
> What is your command line for this? Where are you renaming the directory? You might want to check out the [--track-renames](https://rclone.org/docs/#track-renames) flag

I'm using --track-renames. It works, even if in a roundabout way.

My command line is usually something like

rclone -v --track-renames sync --create-empty-src-dirs A:dir1 B:dir2

Nothing fancy.

File renames work perfectly.
Directory renames "work", but instead of simply renaming the directory, rclone creates a new one with the new name, move the files from the old to the new, and then remove the old one. The end effect is mostly the same. The only actual rename is the renaming (server side move) of the files within the directory.

> Directory renames "work", but instead of simply renaming the directory, rclone creates a new one with the new name, move the files from the old to the new, and then remove the old one. The end effect is mostly the same. The only actual rename is the renaming (server side move) of the files within the directory.

Ah, I see what you mean.

It would take a lot more logic to detect a directory and everything in it is the same then rename it, so rclone goes for renaming each file individually which is less efficient, but as you said the end effect is the same.

I just wanted to mention, that I have the same issue with a Microsoft Onedrive-remote:

`rclone sync --dry-run --tpslimit=10 --create-empty-src-dirs --log-file=rclone.log --progress remote:00_daten/ /home/zukw/00_daten/`
reports 
`<date time> NOTICE: path/to/emtydirectory: Not making directory as dry run is set`
for each empty directory, alltough these empty directory exists already on source and destination.

Hope, that helps a little bit.

issue.title: copy/sync: fix bug on copying empty dirs

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Sync/copy now only creates empty directories when they don't exist on the remote (--create-empty-src-dirs flag) - fixes #2800

<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please

changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

sync/copy now only create empty source directories on dst when they do not exist.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Yes, this is issue #2800
